titlestmt.subtitle: A Subject Log of the Conversation between President Richard M. Nixon and the White House operator
titlestmt.author: Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum
titlestmt.sponsor:

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum

did.abstract: On February 6, 1973, President Richard M. Nixon and the White House operator talked on the telephone at an unknown time between 2:50 pm and 11:50 pm. The White House Telephone taping system captured this recording, which is known as Conversation 043-034 of the White House Tapes. Topics of conversation included ....

scopecontent.head: Conversation Summary
scopecontent.p: On February 6, 1973, President Richard M. Nixon and the White House operator talked on the telephone at an unknown time between 2:50 pm and 11:50 pm. The White House Telephone taping system captured this recording, which is known as Conversation 043-034 of the White House Tapes.

arrangement.head: About the Subject Log
arrangement.p: To assist listeners in understanding the conversation and finding segments pertinent to their own interests, a team of archivists has created a Subject Log, which outlines major topics, names, and organizations in sequential order.

list.item: Logs include action statements, which indicate when someone entered or exited a room. Action statements are underlined.
If a conversation recorded in one of the offices also captures a telephone conversation, a cross-reference to the corresponding telephone recording is provided.
If a telephone recording also captures a conversation taking place in one of the offices, a cross-reference to the corresponding room conversation is provided.
Logs indicate which portions, if any, were reviewed under the 2007 Deed of Gift.

In some cases, the Watergate Special Prosecution Force or court-ordered mandates resulted in a transcript of the entire conversation or portions of conversation. For these portions, archivists have provided a citation to the related transcript.

arrangement.head: Audio Format
arrangement.p: This conversation was recorded to audiotape on a system maintained by the United States Secret Service. The National Archives transferred the original audiotape to Digital Audio Tape (DAT), which, in turn, was later converted to digital audio files.
The audio recording of this conversation has been digitized and made available to the public.

note.label: Digital Remastering Project
note.p: The White House Tapes are currently undergoing preservation remastering, from which digital derivatives will be made and released to the public as appopriate.

controlaccess.head: Determination Categories
controlaccess.p: These processing categories are governed by the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act of 1974 (PRMPA) and the 2007 Deed of Gift.

altformavail.p: The original audio has been converted to digital format and is available to the public as an MP3 file.
The original audio has been converted to digital format and is available to the public as a Broadcast WAVE Format (BWF) file.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access is governed by the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act of 1974 (PRMPA); Nixon Public Access Regulations 36 CFR 1275 of the NARA Code of Federal Regulations, including the 1996 Tapes Settlement Agreement (Appendix A); and protocols related to classified national security information, including Executive Order 13526.
For more information, please contact the Tapes Team at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum: nixon@nara.gov or (301) 837-3290.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The materials processed and released under the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act of 1974 (PRMPA) are considered United States government works and, as such, are not eligible for copyright protection in the United States. Thus, they may be treated as being in the public domain. Materials processed and released under the 2007 Deed of Gift are also considered property of the United States and therefore may be treated as being in the public domain.

Unless expressly stated otherwise, the organization that made this item available makes no warranties about the item and cannot guarantee the accuracy of this rights statement. You are responsible for your own use.

According to 36 C.F.R. § 1254.62, you are responsible for obtaining any necessary permission for use, copying, and publication from copyright holders and for any other applicable provisions of the Copyright Act (Title 17, United States Code).

Certain individuals recorded may claim rights in their recorded voices, under state law. Use of such recorded voices found in this conversation may be subject to these claims. You may need to obtain other permissions for your intended use. For example, other rights such as publicity, privacy, or moral rights may limit how you use the material.
Any materials used for academic research or otherwise should be fully credited with the source.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Conversation 043-034, Audiotape 043, White House Telephone Sound Recordings, White House Tapes, Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum, National Archives and Records Administration.

acqinfo.head: Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act of 1974
acqinfo.p: The Nixon-era White House Tapes are subject to the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act of 1974 (PRMPA). PRMPA, which applies only to the Nixon Presidential Materials, stipulates that those materials relevant to the understanding of Abuse of Governmental Power and Watergate are to be processed and released to the public prior to the release of all other materials. Materials related to the Abuse of Governmental Power and the constitutional and statutory duties of the President and his White House staff are retained by the National Archives. PRMPA mandated the promulgation of access restrictions for the processing of the Nixon Tapes.

The resulting Nixon Public Acccess Regulations 36 CFR 1275 state that the National Archives must segregate and return to the estate of former President Nixon those materials identified as purely "personal-private" or "personal-political," and unrelated to the President's constitutional and statutory duties. This conversation has been processed under these regulations.

acqinfo.head: 2007 Deed of Gift
acqinfo.p: However, in 2007, the estate of Richard Nixon negotiated a Deed of Gift with the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum. By this agreement, materials deemed "personal-political" have been deeded back to the National Archives for release to the public. Materials originally deemed "person-private" have been deeded back to the National Archives, with the exception of materials concerning the medical history or non-Watergate-related personal finances of Richard Nixon or the non-public activities of the First Family.
This conversation has been re-reviewed under the provisions of the 2007 Deed of Gift between the estate of Richard Nixon and the National Archives. Changes in access have been noted.

processinfo.p: Processed by the Tapes Team of the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum, as part of the Fifth Chronological Release: Part III (Chron V, Part III) , and released on .
